p: Cinnamomum camphora (L.) J. Presl (Lauraceae), also known as a camphor tree, is native to tropical Asia, Malaysia and Taiwan, where it is preferably found at altitudes between 1000 and 1800 m asl. In the 17th century, it was introduced in Europe, where it is widely cultivated in gardens [ 1]. It is a very long-lived species that is able to adapt to different types of soil and climatic conditions [ 2]. It displays a solid stem, grey-brownish in color, with deep longitudinal furrows. The leaves are alternate, ovate-elliptic, oblong to lanceolate. Flowers, gathered in axillary inflorescences, are small, white or pale yellow; the fruits are globose drupes, black-purple in color at maturity [ 2].
